subject: Fix dependency specification between subpackages and the main package
commitMessage:
Fix dependency specification between subpackages and the main package

Add %{release} and optionally %{epoch} fields to the "Requires" fileds
of subpackages. By adding %{release} we make sure we have to install
the same release (build) of all the packages, main and subpackages.
%{?epoch:%{epoch}:} adds the epoch if it is set with the "Epoch" field
in the header of the main package.

Change-Id: Ic65985a4d2d80aaa0f099dd061ad5e7b0ca5a277
Signed-off-by: Łukasz Stelmach <l.stelmach@samsung.com>

Patch Set 1:

I know we do not use the Epoch field in Tizen packages. On the other hand using them is very handy during development. When I start working with a particular package I create locally a new branch (devel) and my first commit sets the Release back to 1 and Epoch to 500. This makes the rpm package I build upgrade any installed version of the package without using --force. As I work I bump the Release as needed. Before pushing the finished patch to gerrit I rebase the branch to squash it and remove the Epoch and Release related commits.

I agree that

  Requires: %{name} = %{epoch:%{epoch}:}%{version}-%{release}

is not nearly as pretty as

  Requires: %{name} = %{version}-%{release}

but, whether I like it or not this is the right idiom to set internal dependencies.

Patch Set 1:

btw, your suggested change is not specific to that package, what you are proposing, if actually is needed, would need to be reflected on every single package out there! Is that really something want to do?

Besides, using epochs for local development is lethal, we might introduce this into git by mistake and have a version disaster. So please avoid using this and file a bug against the development tools to enable you to do this without using epoch!

I am not sure this would be a problem. We do not sepcify versions in

gets Epoch thos which depend in this package can still be built without
any problems. Am I wrong?

 > So please avoid using this and file a bug against the development

This isn't about development tools but rather about rpm(1). When I take 
an image with the foo-1.2.3-5-2 rpm package, bumping epoch is the easiest
way to make rpm(1) accept my package as a valid upgrade for the one on the
image *and* force (this is a bit developmental) gbs (and whatever solves
dependencies for it) to use my locally built packages to build other.
